citations.narrative:
A current record of guinea pigs on hand was not available for review during this inspection. There were no inventory
records indicating the number of adult guinea pigs and newborns present since February 18, 2023. Failure to maintain
these records can make it difficult to assess the health of the caviary by identifying animal losses by death or decreased
number of animals born and raised. The facility must maintain records containing the required information for animals
which fully and correctly disclose the number of guinea pigs held, owned, born, raised, and died. Correct by May 6, 2023.

There were accumulations of dried feces and spilled feed covering the majority of the guinea pig enclosures. Enclosures
were last cleaned on April 22, 2023. Infrequent cleaning and sanitation exposes the guinea pigs to disease hazards and
health problems. Primary enclosures must be cleaned often enough to prevent accumulations of excreta, soiled bedding,
and food debris. In addition, the enclosures must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks. Correct by May 5, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
A current record of guinea pigs on hand was not available for review during this inspection. There were no inventory 
records indicating the number of adult guinea pigs and newborns present since February 18, 2023. Failure to maintain 
these records can make it difficult to assess the health of the caviary by identifying animal losses by death or decreased 
number of animals born and raised. The facility must maintain records containing the required information for animals 
which fully and correctly disclose the number of guinea pigs held, owned, born, raised, and died. Correct by May 6, 2023. 
3.31(a)(1) 
   
Sanitation. 
There were accumulations of dried feces and spilled feed covering the majority of the guinea pig enclosures. Enclosures 
were last cleaned on April 22, 2023. Infrequent cleaning and sanitation exposes the guinea pigs to disease hazards and 
health problems. Primary enclosures must be cleaned often enough to prevent accumulations of excreta, soiled bedding, 
and food debris. In addition, the enclosures must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks. Correct by May 5, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
